Award.AwardTitle: Second Order Inference for Nonstationary Time Series
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research is on second order inferences for causal nonstationary processes. While a causal stationary process can be viewed as generated by filtering a set of past innovations, one can allow the filter to be time-changing, and henceforth introduce nonstationarity. Two sets of problems are considered. First, for linear models with nonstationary errors, the investigator addresses the estimation of covariance matrices of the least square estimates, as well as general M-estimates. Second, the PI studies the estimation of time-varying covariance functions, time-varying spectrum and covariance matrices of the observed time series. Simultaneous inferences of autocovariance functions and spectra can be used to study their patterns and trends, and are also of interests. The study requires several tools to be developed for nonstationary processes, including empirical processes, Gaussian approximations, strong invariance principles and large deviations for quadratic forms.

Stationarity has played an important role in classical time series analysis, which basically says that the overall structure does not change over time. However, in many scientific fields, including economics, engineering, environmental science, finance, and neuroscience etc, it is not realistic to believe the observed time series are stationary. Results from the proposed research will be useful in understanding the nature of the data from various disciplines, making forecasts and conclusions.
Furthermore, the second order inferences in the proposal are general and fundamental, and will facilitate further statistical analysis of nonstationary time series.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interllectual Merit

The project considers inferences of time series based on sample covariances and autocovariances, which are of fundamental importance, for both theories and applications. Probability inequalities are established for stationary and nonstationary time series, which are of general use for studies of dependent data. Complex autoregressive and moving average type models are developed for nonlinear and non-Gaussian data, as well as functional time series. The project has the following major outcomes.

The asymptotic distribution of the maximum deviation of sample covariances is obtained for dependent data, which is useful in testing the covariance structure for high dimensional data.

The limiting distributions of the maximum and quadratic deviations of sample autocovariances are obtained under the existence of serial correlations, which is useful in testing serial correlation, constructing confidence bands, bandwidth selection of nonparametric spectral density estimates, and order selection of a linear system etc. To obtain these results, various moment inequalities and large deviations of quadratic forms are established under dependence, which are of potential use for other studies of dependent data.

Nagaev and Rosenthal type inequalities are obtained for general stationary and nonstationary time series. The study is carried under the framework of causal representation coupled with physical dependence measures. Both the framework and the results are useful for other asymptotic studies of time series data.

The generalized autoregressive and moving average (GARMA) models with martingale errors are developed. Many successful models in this line can be viewed as special cases or variations of the GARMA models of Benjamin et al. (2003). Under such a model, unless the link function is an identity function, the error sequence defined in the transformed ARMA model is usually not a martingale difference sequence. Our model continues to enjoy all the interpretations, the link to GLM models, and many of the properties of GAMRA model, but more importantly, with martingale difference as its error sequence, verifiable stationarity and ergodicity conditions are easy to obtain, its Gaussian pseudo­likelihood estimator is consistent, standard model building tools are ready to use, MLE’s asymptotic behavior can be established, and predictions are easier to obtain. 

Convolutional functional autoregressive (CFAR) models are developed. This model can be viewed as a special case of the functional autoregressive models introduced by Bosq (2000). In our model, the autoregressive operator are generated by convolutions, which naturally links the function at time t and argument x to the same argument at previous times. We also consider using Uhlenbeck-Orstein processes as the errors, which add limited roughness to the model. We perform a thorough theoretical analysis of the inferences, which become challenging when the spline approximations are tied with the U-O processes.

 

Broader Impacts

The PI has disseminated the research results through publications in leading journals, departmental seminars, academic conferences and collaborations with other researchers with similar interests. The investigator has interacted with scientists from other fields on the applications of methods developed in this project. The PI supervised one PhD student to research in this direction, who has defended her dissertation. The PI also integrated the outcome of this project into a seminar course for PhD students at Department of Statistics and Biostatistics, Rutgers University.
